titleInfo.title: PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 1430, HONEST AND OPEN NEW EPA SCIENCE TREATMENT ACT OF 2017

extension.searchTitle: PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 1430, HONEST AND OPEN NEW EPA SCIENCE TREATMENT ACT OF 2017; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 54

congVote.result: So the previous question was ordered.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Honest and Open New EPA Science Treatment Act of 2017_Rule for Consideration
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House agreed to H. Res. 229, providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1430) to prohibit the Environmental Protection Agency from proposing, finalizing, or disseminating regulations or assessments based upon science that is not transparent or reproducible, by a recorded vote of 231 ayes to 185 noes, Roll No. 198, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 231 yeas to 189 nays, Roll No. 197.

congVote.result: So the resolution was agreed to.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Honest and Open New EPA Science Treatment Act of 2017_Rule for Consideration
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House agreed to H. Res. 229, providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1430) to prohibit the Environmental Protection Agency from proposing, finalizing, or disseminating regulations or assessments based upon science that is not transparent or reproducible, by a recorded vote of 231 ayes to 185 noes, Roll No. 198, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 231 yeas to 189 nays, Roll No. 197.

titleInfo.title: PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF S.J. RES. 34, PROVIDING FOR CONGRESSIONAL DISAPPROVAL OF A RULE SUBMITTED BY THE FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION

extension.searchTitle: PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF S.J. RES. 34, PROVIDING FOR CONGRESSIONAL DISAPPROVAL OF A RULE SUBMITTED BY THE FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 54

congVote.result: So the previous question was ordered.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Federal Communications Commission relating to ``Protecting the Privacy of Customers of Broadband and Other Telecommunications Services''
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed S.J. Res. 34, providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Federal Communications Commission relating to ``Protecting the Privacy of Customers of Broadband and Other Telecommunications Services'', by a yea-and-nay vote of 215 yeas to 205 nays, Roll No. 202.<P/>H. Res. 230, the rule providing for consideration of the joint resolution (S.J. Res. 34) was agreed to by a recorded vote of 231 ayes to 189 noes, Roll No. 200, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 232 yeas to 184 nays, Roll No. 199.

congVote.result: So the resolution was agreed to.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Federal Communications Commission relating to ``Protecting the Privacy of Customers of Broadband and Other Telecommunications Services''
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed S.J. Res. 34, providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Federal Communications Commission relating to ``Protecting the Privacy of Customers of Broadband and Other Telecommunications Services'', by a yea-and-nay vote of 215 yeas to 205 nays, Roll No. 202.<P/>H. Res. 230, the rule providing for consideration of the joint resolution (S.J. Res. 34) was agreed to by a recorded vote of 231 ayes to 189 noes, Roll No. 200, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 232 yeas to 184 nays, Roll No. 199.

titleInfo.title: United States Senate Joint Resolution 34 (115th Congress)
United States Senate Joint Resolution 34 (115th Congress)
United States Senate Joint Resolution 34 (115th Congress)
RAISING A QUESTION OF THE PRIVILEGES OF THE HOUSE

extension.searchTitle: RAISING A QUESTION OF THE PRIVILEGES OF THE HOUSE; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 54

congVote.result: So the motion to table was agreed to.
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: Representative Lofgren rose to a question of the privileges of the House and submitted a resolution. The Chair ruled that the resolution did not present a question of the privileges of the House. Subsequently, Representative Lofgren appealed the ruling of the chair and Representative Flores moved to table the appeal. Agreed to the motion to table the appeal of the ruling of the Chair by a yea-and-nay vote of 228 yeas to 190 nays with 2 answering ``present'', Roll No. 201.

congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed S.J. Res. 34, providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Federal Communications Commission relating to ``Protecting the Privacy of Customers of Broadband and Other Telecommunications Services'', by a yea-and-nay vote of 215 yeas to 205 nays, Roll No. 202.

titleInfo.title: PROTOCOL TO THE NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY OF 1949 ON THE ACCESSION OF MONTENEGRO--Continued

extension.searchTitle: PROTOCOL TO THE NORTH ATLANTIC TREATY OF 1949 ON THE ACCESSION OF MONTENEGRO--Continued; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 54

congVote.result: Two-thirds of the Senators voting, a quorum being present, having voted in the affirmative, the resolution of ratification is agreed to.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Protocol to the North Atlantic Treaty of 1949 on the Accession of Montenegro
Protocol to the North Atlantic Treaty of 1949 on the Accession of Montenegro
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: : By 97 yeas to 2 nays (Vote No. 98), two-thirds of the Senators present having voted in the affirmative, Senate agreed to the resolution of Advice and Consent to Ratification to Treaty Doc. 114-12, Protocol to the North Atlantic Treaty of 1949 on the Accession of Montenegro, after having passed through its various parliamentary stages, up to and including the presentation of the resolution of ratification, and taking action on the following amendments proposed thereto:

: By 97 yeas to 2 nays (Vote No. 98), two-thirds of the Senators present having voted in the affirmative, Senate agreed to the resolution of Advice and Consent to Ratification to Treaty Doc. 114-12, Protocol to the North Atlantic Treaty of 1949 on the Accession of Montenegro, after having passed through its various parliamentary stages, up to and including the presentation of the resolution of ratification, and taking action on the following amendments proposed thereto:
